vareagan: I too have SAD, Seasonal Affective Disorder. No irony there. Most of my family has it. babyruth728: My mom had seasonal depression. She always used full spectrum light bulbs in the entire house and kept them on during the day and evening which seemed to help. The bottomless pit feeling is pretty terrifying. Thank you for telling your story. It’s important.
itsraemarkable: The sun is coming soon! She always comes back and with all the love she had before. Also I have recently realized that I give my self way to much shit about being a good adult.. My aunt told me recently that it’s ok to do things that might seem less like the ideal adult behavior if it means you life is easier. For me, I hated food shopping and cooking breakfast. So I’ve started using the free grocery pick up like they have at Walmart so I don’t have to go in the store and I’ve started buying those uncrustable things because I like peanut butter and jelly for breakfast but don’t feel like making it. Those things seem like such stupid things to hate.. like be an adult and make yourself a sandwich. But I don’t have to.. because I’m an adult and can do whatever I want. Give yourself this kindness. Being an adult doesn’t mean you have to conform to societal standards. You are the queen of not taking societies bullshit. That can apply here too.

crotchlessyogapants: I am the weirdo who is happy in the winter and depressed AF in the summer, but maybe one of those sun lamps might help? I used one for a while because I have a "circadian rhythm disorder"--I tried every prescription sleep aid, every non-prescription sleep aid, all the "don't do anything but sleep in bed" bullshit, and was down to 4 hours a night. Resetting my clock with the lamp was life-changing. I tell this story because I was skeptical as fuck that some stupid light would help, but I gave it a chance and it did. According to my sleep dr., it needs to be 10,000 lux. I hope you can continue to take care of yourself and get through this. Depression sucks ass.

Thank you so much for sharing with us ❤️ it helps to feel not so alone
caseiiandjunior: Literally me. Had to do school run, had a cry then chucked on clothes while thinking and trying not to cry and be present and involved but I just couldn't. I went to autopilot, for clothes on went and took my child to school and I came in, sat down cried, debated a day wine (didn't but really that's the mood) and sat on my couch for three hours. katieallencoaching: I feel you and am in the same boat right now. Sending hugs ❤️
apeach_intexas: That part where you said you feel like you're failing as an adult...damn, that hit home. Hard. My depression prevents me from doing the most mundane, "adulty" shit and I hate it. But we are NOT failures. We just have an illness. We wouldn't think someone with a physical illness was failing as an adult if their sickness prevented them from doing little things. The best, and sometimes most difficult, thing we can do is cut ourselves some slack. Like you said, you've gotten through it before and you'll get through it again. We can do this. ❤️
samantha_kay_75: Thank you for talking about difficult things. Sending you love ♥️
plantvibz: Thank you for sharing with us❤ here is my share...I struggle HARD every year.. This year...I broke my ankle.. Sitting here listening to the rain in a dark room very dependent on others unable to get the medical help I need has me feeling pretty low. I sat by the window watching most my plants drowning from this rain storm just sitting out of my reach. The things that give me a tomorrow to look forward to..I pictured the tingly happy feeling I'd have if I could walk out and save them. Then I realized I'm being shown a life harder then my usual for a reason. I'm going to remember that feeling of physical defeat forever and make myself get up and do something even in the times my mind tells me NO and to just give up..
anunsafetaco: You're doing great! Sometimes taking your meds and being sad is about all you can do. As a fellow depressed person, I get it. We're all here for you, as cliché as it sounds
deannr78: Im right there with you right now.
bevinsparty: I too struggle seasonally with depression and am so light sensitive. no_victoria_no: Preach! This time of year is hard for me too. You are not alone. And remember, the sky is always blue, even when the clouds make it grey. It doesn't fix anything, just reminds you that it's ok to feel the feelings, you are not your feelings, and it too will pass. ❤️
